title: Operation: Rabbit
descriptions:
Operation: Rabbit (1952) is a classic Looney Tunes short featuring Wile E. Coyote and Bugs Bunny, marking one of the earliest pairings where Wile E. Coyote speaks and positions himself as a self-proclaimed “genius” predator. The cartoon plays as a battle of wits, with Wile E. Coyote meticulously planning elaborate schemes to capture and eat Bugs, only to be outsmarted at every turn by Bugs’s calm sarcasm and crafty countermeasures.

The short begins with Wile E. Coyote introducing himself directly to the audience as a super-genius, presenting the pursuit of Bugs Bunny as an “operation,” a scientific endeavor rather than mere hunting. He identifies Bugs’s rabbit hole as the target and devises a series of contraptions and stratagems meant to ensure success. Bugs, coolly aware of the coyote’s presence from the start, responds with his usual “What’s up, Doc?” nonchalance, treating each new trap as an opportunity to gently humiliate the self-important predator.

Wile E.’s first plots are simple but quickly escalate. He tries to lure Bugs with bait and snares, then shifts to more complicated devices involving ropes, pulleys, and explosives. Bugs plays along just enough to reverse the mechanism or lead Wile E. into his own trap. In a signature gag, the coyote prepares a door rigged to drop a heavy object on whoever opens it. Bugs, feigning helpfulness, reroutes the setup or invites Wile E. to demonstrate, resulting in the coyote being flattened by his own device. The pattern becomes a comedic rhythm: Wile E. unveils an impressive plan with technical flair, only for Bugs to casually undermine it with a single, sly move or with a line of playful banter.

Determined to prove his intellectual superiority, Wile E. produces blueprints and engineering-like solutions: a subterranean tunneling attempt that pops him up in the wrong place; an explosive-laden scheme turned back on him by Bugs’s quick switch; an electrified contraption that ends up zapping its creator. In another memorable bit, Wile E. tries to smoke Bugs out of the rabbit hole, only for the smoke to backfire in a literal and figurative sense, leaving Wile E. coughing and singed while Bugs emerges unruffled.

Throughout, the comedy leans heavily on contrast. Wile E. speaks in lofty, precise diction, framing his hunt as a scientific project and even scolding the audience for not appreciating the complexities of genius. Bugs counters with laid-back charm, pretending to cooperate or innocently misinterpret directions just long enough to twist each setup to his advantage. The verbal sparring is punctuated by visual slapstick: dropped anvils, misfired explosives, flipped switches, and contraptions that seem engineered to boomerang.

As Wile E.’s failures mount, he doubles down with grander operations. He constructs a complex machine meant to capture Bugs with impeccable timing and multiple chained reactions. Bugs, examining the device, simply unplugs a cord or nudges a lever, collapsing the whole system in an instant. In another gag, the coyote attempts disguise or stealth, creeping toward the rabbit hole, only for Bugs to greet him like a neighbor and offer unhelpful “assistance” that leads Wile E. right back into the danger zone of his own trap.

The cartoon’s climax involves Wile E. introducing an especially intricate plan, presented as foolproof, with a flourish of smug confidence. Bugs listens politely, then, with a few words and a simple adjustment, ensures the coyote bears the full brunt of the plan’s catastrophic failure. The final beat typically showcases Wile E. dazed and battered, yet still clinging to the belief in his superior intellect, while Bugs delivers a quick, cutting line that sums up the absurdity of the situation.

Operation: Rabbit stands out among Bugs Bunny shorts for the way it rebrands Wile E. Coyote from the nearly silent pursuer of the Road Runner into a verbose, egotistical mastermind whose undoing is his own hubris. The humor arises not just from physical comedy but from the interplay of persona: the self-styled genius against the genuinely clever rabbit. The short ends with Bugs triumphant, unscathed, and amused, while the coyote, singed, squashed, and outwitted, must concede—if only to the audience—that Operation: Rabbit was thoroughly, and hilariously, compromised.
